{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3605020,"name":"Chase Eid","username":"PixL","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pixl/{size}/250824_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T13:33:33.242Z","cooked":"

I’m wondering if we were to get a slip ring of the amp ratings would have to be 40a or the same as the recommenced wire gauge. I know that those currents are fine over a short amount of time but the rules don’t specify whether it’s the maximum stained amp ratings that must equal the breaker used on the circuit. I’m assuming that I can use a 20a slip ring with a 40amp breaker, since 12 gauge wire is rated for that amount, but I’m not sure what an inspector would say

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T13:33:33.242Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":24,"reads":491,"readers_count":490,"score":218.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Chase Eid","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69000,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3605029,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T14:13:49.879Z","cooked":"

An inspector would invoke R623 and ask if it’s appropriate to send 40A through a 20A device.

Short answer, it isn’t.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T14:13:49.879Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":469,"readers_count":468,"score":163.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R623","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R623 | FRCTools","clicks":40}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605042,"name":"Chase Eid","username":"PixL","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pixl/{size}/250824_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T14:32:04.082Z","cooked":"

Then why do we send 40a through 20a wire (actually up to 80)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T14:32:40.682Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":434,"readers_count":433,"score":96.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Chase Eid","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69000,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605043,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T14:32:56.143Z","cooked":"

There’s precedent in other parts of the rules to use “any rating” (R802), so if you could find a slip ring that was rated 20A continuous, 40A intermittent, I think you’d prevail with an inspector that that was OK downstream of a 40A breaker. (Even though that’s unsound on an engineering basis generally, these robots just have to not catch fire for 2.5 minutes of operation.)

Ironically, that suggests that finding a component without an explicitly stated current rating is less likely to be disapproved, based on the LRI’s judgment of the argument “well, it has 12AWG wires, so it’s ‘appropriately gauged’ as required in R623 and therefore OK where a 12 AWG wire would be OK”.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T14:32:56.143Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":416,"readers_count":415,"score":128.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R802","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R802 | FRCTools","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/4","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605046,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T14:35:27.059Z","cooked":"
PixL:

Then why do we send 40a through 20a wire (actually up to 80)

There’s an explicit provision for that in the rules (R622). The 20A rating is an NEC rating for continuous use (defined as drawing the maximum current over 3 or more hours, IIRC) including inside a wall without airflow and these robots run about 1% as long as that and the robot wires usually have pretty good airflow around them and intermittent currents.

Edit: the NEC limit is actually 30A for 12AWG THHN/XHHW/USE-2 wiring, derated to 80% of that (24A) for continuous loads. We often short-hand the rating of 12AWG wire to be 20A because that’s the size breaker that we’re allowed to land NM-B (“Romex”) cables on. That’s because NM-B is only rated to 60°C, while THHN/XHHW has a higher temp rating for the conductor’s insulation (90°C) in dry locations.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T14:46:24.410Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":354,"readers_count":353,"score":155.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R622","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R622 | FRCTools","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/5","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605110,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T18:01:06.880Z","cooked":"
sokoloff:

THHN/XHHW has a higher temp rating for the conductor’s insulation (90°C) in dry locations.

And furthermore, it’s pretty rare that you can ever use that 90C rating because the terminations also have to be rated for it…and that’s pretty rare.

Back in FRC-land, there have been exceptions made in the past for certain current ratings. Here’s an example:

image977×182 32.9 KB

from: https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2022/FRC2022RapidReact-QandAExport.pdf

In this case, it seems that REV was able to “re-rate” a COTS part, and have that rating apply to all instances, even those not purchased from REV.

Reminder that Q&A only applies to a single season (although this legality seems to be persistent in practice). If you had a similar question, you’d need to ask it during the actual season you needed the device for.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T18:01:06.880Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":267,"readers_count":266,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2022/FRC2022RapidReact-QandAExport.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605216,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T21:08:56.033Z","cooked":"
PixL:

Then why do we send 40a through 20a wire (actually up to 80)

It’s a good lesson in what ratings mean

Wires will pass pretty much whatever current you push through them, that’s not the point of the rating. The real question is “when does something bad happen”?

Badness is much more a function of the insulation’s failure modes and the environment, over the gauge of the conductor.

IE, I can put a metric ton of current through 18AWG wire as long as it’s cooled with a nice non-conductive oil jacket.

Here’s a 30A slip ring, possibly good enough?

Of note, it brings me great joy that the second google result for “40A slip ring” points back to an FRC question:

image1426×640 102 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T21:11:21.116Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":41.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/Taidacent-Collector-Rotary-Electrical-Contact/dp/B07PY1SZ2T?th=1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Taidacent 2 Wires 15A 20A 30A 40A 60A Slip Ring Collector Ring Rotary Electrical Contact (30A) - Amazon.com","clicks":18}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605285,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T23:22:24.115Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Here’s a 30A slip ring, possibly good enough?

If you are fine using a brushed motor, current limiting the motor to 30A phase current (or whatever the intermittent rating is, that slip ring likely comes out of the same factory as moflons) and putting no sensors on the other end (meaning no feedback control), than sure.

The problem that makes slip rings impractical for FRC is that is extremely hard to find slip rings with enough wires to run both motors and sensors while having wires that are rated for FRC levels of current because nobody makes them because the rest of the world doesn’t want them. Combined power and signal slip rings don’t usually have power wires that go above 10A. You could try searching on moflon or senring directly, but I haven’t ever found any that are suitable for FRC, much less so below the $600 cost limit which is going to be even more problematic due to tarriffs because most slip rings come from China.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T23:22:24.115Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":45.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.moflon.com/slip-ring/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Slip Rings - Standard In Stock & Custom Solutions - MOFLON","clicks":5},{"url":"https://www.senring.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Slip Ring | Rotary Unions Solution Manufacturer_Senring","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605310,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T23:54:22.238Z","cooked":"

Taxes and tariffs do not count toward the $600 limit. (Blue box in R301.)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-27T23:55:43.075Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":25.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500654,"topic_slug":"amp-ratings-for-slip-rings","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://frctools.com/2025/rule/R301","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Rule R301 | FRCTools","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/amp-ratings-for-slip-rings/500654/9","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3605312,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-27T23:59:00.049Z","cooked":"

Many distributors can and have increased costs directly in response to the tariffs, which is not except from the cost cap. And even if an item doesn’t ship from China, some part of its supply chain usually does, which still causes a significant cost increase.
